entry.title: SkyKnit: When knitters teamed up with a neural network
entry.summary:
[Make Caows and Shapcho - MeganAnn]
[Pitsilised Koekirjad Cushion Sampler Poncho - Maeve]
[Lacy 2047Â -Â michaela112358]
I use algorithms called neural networks to write humor. Whatâ€™s fun about neural networks is they learn by example - give them a bunch of some sort of data, and theyâ€™ll try to figure out rules that let them imitate it. They power corporate finances, recognize faces, translate text, and more. I, however, like to give them silly datasets. Iâ€™ve trained neural networks to generate newÂ paintÂ colors, newÂ Halloween costumes, and newÂ candy heart messages. When the problem is tough, the results are mixed (there was that one candy heart that just said HOLE).
One of the toughest problems Iâ€™ve ever tried? Knitting patterns.
I knew almost nothing about knitting whenÂ @JohannaB@wandering.shopÂ sent me the suggestion one day. She sent me to theÂ Ravelry knitting site, and to its adults-only, often-indecorousÂ LSG forum, who as you will see are amazing people. (When asked how I should describe them, one wrote â€œdonâ€™t forget the glitter and swearing!â€)
And so, we embarked uponÂ Operation Hilarious Knitting Disaster.
The knitters helped me crowdsource a dataset of 500 knitting patterns, ranging from hats to squids to unmentionables. JC Briar exported another 4728 patterns fromÂ the siteÂ stitch-maps.com.Â
I gave the knitting patterns to a couple of neural networks that I collectively named â€œSkyKnitâ€. Then, not knowing if they had produced anything remotely knittable, I started posting the patterns. Hereâ€™s an early example.
MrsNoddyNoddy wrote, â€œitâ€™s difficult to explain why 6395, 71, 70, 77 is so asthma-inducingly funny.â€ (It seems that a 6000-plus stitch count is, as GloriaHanlon put it,Â â€œoptimismâ€).Â
As training progressed, and as I tried some higher-performance models, SkyKnit improved. Hereâ€™s a later example.
Even at its best, SkyKnit had problems. It would sometimes repeat rows, or leave them out entirely. It could count rows fairly reliably up to about 22, but after that would start haphazardly guessing random largish numbers. SkyKnit also had trouble counting stitches, and would confidently declare at the end of certain lines that it contained 12 stitches when it was nothing of the sort.
But the knitters began knitting them. This possibly marks one of the few times in history when a computer generated code to be executed by humans.
[Mystery laceÂ - datasock]
[Reverss ShawlÂ - citikas]
[Frost - Odonata]
The knitters didnâ€™t follow SkyKnitâ€™s directions exactly, as it turns out. For most of its patterns, doing them exactly as written would result in the pattern immediately unraveling (due to many dropped stitches), or turning into long whiplike tentacles (due to lots of leftover stitches). Or, to make the row counts match up with one another, they would have had to keep repeating the pattern until theyâ€™d reached a multiple of each row count - sometimes this was possible after a few repeats, while other times they would have had to make the pattern tens of thousands of stitches long. And other times, missing rows made the directions just plain impossible.Â
So, the knitters just started fixing SkyKnitâ€™s patterns.
Knitters are very good at debugging patterns, as it turns out. Not only are there a lot of knitters who are coders, but debugging is such a regular part of knitting that the complicated math becomes second nature. Notation is not always consistent, some patterns need to be adjusted for size, and some simply have mistakes. The knitters were used to taking these problems in stride. When working with one of SkyKnitâ€™s patterns, GloriaHanlon wrote, â€œIâ€™m trying not to fudge too much, basically working on the principle that theÂ pattern was written by an elderly relative who doesnâ€™t speak much English.â€
Each pattern required a different debugging approach, and sometimes knitters would each produce their own very different-looking versions. Here are three versions ofÂ â€œPaw Not Pointed 2 Stitch 2â€³.
[Top - ActualJellyfish;Â Middle - LadyAurian;Â Bottom (sock version) - ShoelessJane]
Once, knitter MeganAnn came across a stitch that didnâ€™t even exist (something SkyKnit called â€™pbkâ€™). So she had to improvise. â€œI googled it and went with the first definition I got, which was â€˜place bead and knitâ€™.â€ The resulting pattern is â€œRibbed Rib Ribâ€ below (note bead).
[Ribbed Rib Rib - MeganAnn]
Even debugged, the patterns were weird. Like, really, really nonhumanly weird.
â€œI love how organic it comes out,â€œ wrote Vastra. SylviaTX agreed, loving â€œthe organic seeming randomness. Like bubbles on water or something,â€Â
SkyKnitâ€™s patterns were also a pain.Â Michaela112358 called Row 15 of Mystery Lace (above) â€œa bit of a head melterâ€, commenting that it â€œlacked the rhythm that you tend to get with a normal patternâ€. Maeve_ish wrote that Shetland Bird Pat â€œmade my brain hurt so I went to bed.â€ ShoelessJane asked, â€œOkay, now who here has read Snow Crash?â€
[Winder Socks (2 versions) - TotesMyName]
â€œI was laughing a few days ago because I was trying to math a Skyknit pattern and my brainâ€¦froze. Like, no longer could number at all. I stared blankly at my scribbles and at the screen wondering what had happened til somehow I rebooted. Yup, Skyknit crashed my brain.â€ - Rayn63
[Paw chain 2Â -Â HMSChicago]
On the pattern SkyKnit called â€œCherry and Acorns Twisted Toâ€:
â€œCouple notes on the knitting experience, which while funny wasnâ€™t terribly pleasurable: Because thereâ€™s no rhythm or symmetry to the pattern, I felt I was white-knuckling it through each line, really having to concentrate. There are also some stitch combinations that arenâ€™t very comfortable to execute physically, YO, SSK in particular.
That said, Iâ€™m nearly tempted to add a bit of random AI lace to a project, perhaps as cuffs on a sweater or a short-row lace panel in part of a scarf, likeÂ Sylvia McFaddenÂ does in many of her shawl designs. As another person in the thread said, it would add a touch of spider-on-LSD.â€ -SarahScully
[cherry and acorns twisted toÂ - Sarah Scully]
BridgetJâ€™s comments onÂ â€œButnet Scarfâ€:
â€œFour repeats in to this oddball, daintily alien-looking 8-row lace pattern, and I have, improbably, begun to internalize it and get in to a rhythm like every other lace pattern.
I still have a lingering suspicion that Iâ€™m knitting a pattern that could someday communicate to an AI that I want to play a game of Global Thermonuclear War, but I suppose at least Iâ€™ll have a scarf at the end of it?â€ -BridgetJ
[butnet scarfÂ - BridgetJ]
There was also this beauty of a pattern, that SkyKnit called â€œTiny Baby Whale Sotoâ€. GloriaHanlon managed somehow to knit it and described it asÂ â€œa bona fide eldritch horror. Think Slenderman meets Cthulu and you wouldnâ€™t be far wrong.â€
[Tiny Baby Whale Soto - GloriaHanlon]
Other than being a bit afraid of Tiny Baby Whale Soto, the knitters seem happy to do the bidding of SkyKnit, brain melts and all.
â€œI cast on for a lovely MKAL with a designer I totally trust and became immediately suspicious because the pattern made sense. All rows increase in an orderly manner. There are no â€œhuh?â€ moments. There are no maths at allâ€¦it has all been done for me. I thought I would be happy, yo. Instead, I am kind of missing the brain scrambling and I keep looking for pigs and tentacles. Go figure.â€ - Rayn63
Check out the rest of the SkyKnit-generated patterns, and the glorious rainbow of weird test-knits atÂ SkyKnit: The CollectionÂ and InfiKnit.Â
Thereâ€™s also a great article in the Atlantic that talks a bit more about the debugging.Â
If you feel so inspired (and donâ€™t mind the kind-hearted yet vigorous swearing), join the conversation on theÂ LSG Ravelry SkyKnit threadÂ - many of SkyKnitâ€™s creations have not yet been test-knit at all, and others transform with every new knitterâ€™s interpretation. Compare notes, commiserate, and do SkyKnitâ€™s inscrutable bidding!
Heck yeah there is bonus material this week. Have some neural net-generated knitting & crochet titles. Some of them are mixed with metal band names for added creepiness. Become a supporter of AI Weirdness to get more like these:
Chicken Shrug Snuggle Features Cartube Party Filled Booties Corm Fullenflops Womp Mittens Socks of Death Tomb of Sweater Shawl Ruins

entry.title: SkyKnit: How an AI Took Over an Adult Knitting Community
entry.summary: Quirky knitters teamed up with a neural-network creator to generate new types of tentacled, cozy shapes.

entry.title: Write good examples by starting with real code
entry.summary: When I write about programming, I spend a lot of time trying to come up with good examples. I havenâ€™t seen a lot written about how to make examples, so hereâ€™s a little bit about my approach to writing examples! The basic idea here is to start with real code that you wrote and then remove irrelevant details to make it into a self-contained example instead of coming up with examples out of thin air. Iâ€™ll talk about two kinds of examples: realistic examples and suprising examples. good examples are realistic To see why examples should be realistic, letâ€™s first talk about an unrealistic example! Letâ€™s say weâ€™re trying to explain Python lambdas (which is just the first concept I thought of). You could give this example, of using map and a lambda to double a set of numbers. numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4â€¦

entry.title: v1.11.0
entry.summary:
Added: support an experimental template for YouTube feed ðŸ“º Demo | Source
Aggregate content from any YouTube channel rss url https://www.youtube.com/feeds/videos.xml?channel_id=<replace_with_channel_id> Videos are embedded via iframe and loading accelerated by youtube-lite-embed Ads are reduced thanks to YouTube's policy for embedded videos ðŸ™ƒ Works on mobile devices with butter smooth horizontal scroll. Caveat: the template works only with YouTube content. You cannot mix textual RSS feed or other video sources such as Vimeo. Changed: Default HTML template meta tag adjusted to match convention Changed: sources in template data is now ordered by last update timestamp (as opposed to alphabetical) Thank you @PiyushLosalka
